Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation2: Before starting a large-scale project tomorrow, the carpenter needs to read and interpret blueprints, drawings, and technical documents
Story: I sat at my workbench, the scent of sawdust clinging to my clothes, blueprints spread out before me. Tomorrow, I’d start the biggest project of my career—a custom library for a client who expected perfection. Every line on the drawings demanded my full attention, every measurement a potential pitfall if I missed a detail. My phone buzzed, jolting me from my concentration. It was Thursday—time for my weekly call with my parents. I could already hear my mother’s gentle voice, asking about my week, my father’s quiet questions about my health. They counted on these calls, a thread connecting us across the miles. But the blueprints stared back at me, reminding me of the hours I still needed to spend, the mistakes I couldn’t afford. My heart tugged in two directions: the daughter who didn’t want to disappoint, the carpenter who couldn’t risk distraction. I stared at the phone, torn between the warmth of family and the weight of responsibility, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
